classifications.note: CM velocity: $\vec{v}_{CM} = \frac{d\vec{r}_{CM}}{dt} = \frac{\sum m_i\vec{v}_i}{\sum m_i}$, CM acceleration: $\vec{a}_{CM} = \frac{d\vec{v}_{CM}}{dt} = \frac{\sum m_i\vec{a}_i}{\sum m_i} = \frac{\vec{F}_{net,ext}}{M}$, total momentum: $\vec{p}_{total} = M\vec{v}_{CM}$

principles.statement: Center of mass motion follows fundamental physical laws: Position Definition: $\vec{r}_{CM} = \frac{1}{M}\sum m_i\vec{r}_i$; Mass-weighted average position; Foundation for all CM concepts. Velocity Relationship: $\vec{v}_{CM} = \frac{d\vec{r}_{CM}}{dt} = \frac{1}{M}\sum m_i\vec{v}_i$; Mass-weighted average velocity; Directly related to total momentum: $\vec{p}_{total} = M\vec{v}_{CM}$. Acceleration Theorem: $\vec{a}_{CM} = \frac{d\vec{v}_{CM}}{dt} = \frac{1}{M}\sum m_i\vec{a}_i = \frac{\vec{F}_{net,ext}}{M}$; CM acceleration depends only on external forces; Internal forces cancel in pairs (Newton's 3rd law). Newton's Second Law: $\vec{F}_{net,ext} = M\vec{a}_{CM}$; CM moves as if all mass concentrated there and all external forces applied there; Powerful simplification of complex systems. Component Form: x: F_net,x = Ma_CM,x; y: F_net,y = Ma_CM,y; z: F_net,z = Ma_CM,z; Can analyze motion component-wise. Conservation Implications: If $\vec{F}_{net,ext} = 0$, then $\vec{a}_{CM} = 0$; $\vec{v}_{CM}$ constant; Total momentum conserved; CM moves with constant velocity. Time Evolution: Can integrate acceleration to find velocity: $\vec{v}_{CM}(t) = \vec{v}_{CM}(0) + \int_0^t \vec{a}_{CM} dt$; And position: $\vec{r}_{CM}(t) = \vec{r}_{CM}(0) + \int_0^t \vec{v}_{CM} dt$. Applications: Projectile motion of complex objects; Multi-body systems; Collision analysis; Rocket motion; Astronomical systems.
principles.application: Calculate CM velocity and acceleration. Apply Newton's second law to CM motion. Analyze systems with external forces. Use CM motion for collision analysis. Solve time evolution problems. Apply to complex multi-body systems.

principles.analogy: Like the navigation system of a fleet of ships - the fleet's center (CM) follows a course determined by overall currents and winds (external forces), while individual ships might maneuver around each other (internal motions), but these internal movements don't affect the fleet's overall progression

worked_examples.title: CM Motion Under Gravity
worked_examples.problem: Three masses connected by light rods: 2 kg at (0,0), 3 kg at (4,0), 1 kg at (0,3). System in free fall. Find: (a) CM position, (b) CM acceleration, (c) CM position after 2 seconds from rest.

step_by_step.explanation: Only gravity acts: F_net,x = 0, F_net,y = -Mg = -6×9.8 = -58.8 N
CM follows perfect parabolic trajectory as if it were a single particle; Internal forces don't affect CM motion

worked_examples.final_answer: CM position: (2, 0.5) m; CM acceleration: (0, -9.8) m/s²; After 2 seconds: (2, -19.1) m; CM follows projectile motion under gravity

image.caption: Center of mass motion under gravitational acceleration

worked_examples.title: System with Multiple External Forces
worked_examples.problem: Two boxes connected by string: 4 kg on smooth surface with 10 N pull right, 2 kg hanging vertically. Find CM acceleration.

step_by_step.explanation: 4 kg box: 10 N right (pull), 2 kg box: 19.6 N down (gravity), Normal forces cancel vertically for 4 kg box
F_net,x = 10 N (right); F_net,y = -19.6 N (down) for hanging mass
Tension in string is internal force; Doesn't affect CM motion; Only external forces matter
Could solve for individual accelerations then weight average; More complex but should give same result

worked_examples.final_answer: CM acceleration = 3.67 m/s² at 63.0° below horizontal; CM motion determined solely by external forces

image.caption: Center of mass acceleration with multiple external forces

classifications.note: For isolated systems: $\vec{F}_{ext} = 0$ → $\vec{a}_{CM} = 0$ → $\vec{v}_{CM}$ constant, total momentum: $\vec{p}_{total} = M\vec{v}_{CM}$ constant, in explosions: CM continues original trajectory, in collisions: CM velocity unchanged

principles.statement: Conservation principles provide fundamental insights into CM motion: Momentum Conservation: In isolated system ($\vec{F}_{ext} = 0$), total momentum constant; $\vec{p}_{total} = M\vec{v}_{CM}$ constant; Therefore $\vec{v}_{CM}$ constant; CM moves with constant velocity. Energy Considerations: Kinetic energy of CM: $K_{CM} = \frac{1}{2}Mv_{CM}^2$; Total KE = K_CM + K_internal; In elastic collisions, both may be conserved; In inelastic collisions, K_internal changes. Isolated Systems: No external forces; CM moves with constant velocity; Internal motions don't affect CM trajectory; Examples: particles in free space, colliding objects in vacuum. Collision Processes: In any collision (brief interaction), external forces often negligible; CM velocity unchanged during collision; Useful reference frame: CM frame has total momentum = 0. Explosion Dynamics: Fragments fly in all directions; CM continues original trajectory; Vector sum of fragment momenta = 0 in CM frame; Total momentum conserved. Rocket Systems: Variable mass; CM still follows $\vec{F}_{ext} = \frac{d}{dt}(M\vec{v}_{CM})$; Thrust is internal force; Exhaust momentum affects CM motion. CM Frame Advantages: Total momentum = 0; Often symmetric solutions; Simplified mathematics; Natural for collision analysis; Clear physical interpretation. Applications: Particle physics experiments; Astronomical systems; Molecular dynamics; Engineering design; Sports analysis.

worked_examples.title: Explosion CM Trajectory
worked_examples.problem: A 5 kg projectile fired at 50 m/s, 30° above horizontal explodes at highest point into three pieces: 2 kg at 20 m/s up, 1 kg at 30 m/s horizontally right, 2 kg piece. Find CM position 2 seconds after explosion.

step_by_step.explanation: Initial: v_x = 50 cos30° = 43.3 m/s, v_y = 50 sin30° = 25 m/s; Time to highest point: t = v_y/g = 25/9.8 = 2.55 s
In isolated system (explosion internal), v_CM unchanged: v_CM,x = 43.3 m/s, v_CM,y = 0
CM follows original parabolic trajectory despite explosion; Fragments move relative to CM

worked_examples.final_answer: CM position 2 seconds after explosion = (197.0 m, 12.28 m); CM continues original projectile trajectory

image.caption: Center of mass trajectory in explosion scenario

worked_examples.title: Collision in CM Frame
worked_examples.problem: Two particles: 3 kg at 8 m/s east, 2 kg at 6 m/s west. They collide elastically. Analyze in CM frame.

step_by_step.explanation: u₁ = v₁ - v_CM = 8 - 2.4 = 5.6 m/s east; u₂ = v₂ - v_CM = -6 - 2.4 = -8.4 m/s east (8.4 m/s west)

step_by_step.step: Verify zero momentum in CM frame

step_by_step.explanation: In CM frame, elastic collision reverses velocities: u₁f = -5.6 m/s east = 5.6 m/s west; u₂f = 8.4 m/s east
v₁f = u₁f + v_CM = -5.6 + 2.4 = -3.2 m/s (3.2 m/s west); v₂f = u₂f + v_CM = 8.4 + 2.4 = 10.8 m/s east
In CM frame, elastic collision simply reverses velocities; Much simpler than lab frame analysis

worked_examples.final_answer: CM velocity = 2.4 m/s east; In CM frame: velocities reverse in elastic collision; Final lab velocities: 3 kg at 3.2 m/s west, 2 kg at 10.8 m/s east

image.caption: Elastic collision analysis in center of mass frame

principles.statement: Center of mass motion principles extend to complex modern applications: Variable Mass Systems: General form: $\vec{F}_{ext} = \frac{d}{dt}(M\vec{v}_{CM})$; Must account for mass changes; Rocket equation: $M\frac{d\vec{v}_{CM}}{dt} = \vec{F}_{ext} + \vec{v}_{rel}\frac{dM}{dt}$; Relative velocity important. Rocket Propulsion: Mass decreases over time; Exhaust gases carry away momentum; CM motion determined by external forces and thrust; Thrust = $\vec{v}_{exhaust}\frac{dM}{dt}$. Multi-Body Systems: Complex internal motions; CM still follows simple trajectory; Examples: solar system (Sun contains 99.8% mass, so CM near Sun); Binary stars (CM between them). Biological Applications: Animal locomotion analysis; Sports biomechanics; Human movement studies; CM trajectory optimization for efficiency. Engineering Dynamics: Vehicle stability analysis; Aircraft center of gravity; Structural dynamics; Vibration analysis; Robot motion planning. Astronomical Systems: Galactic dynamics; Planetary system formation; Orbital mechanics; Dark matter studies through CM motions. Modern Physics: Particle physics collisions; Quantum system analogs; Relativistic CM concepts; Cosmological applications. Problem-Solving Strategies: Identify all external forces; Calculate total mass and CM position; Apply $\vec{F}_{ext} = M\vec{a}_{CM}$; Integrate for motion; Use conservation laws when applicable.

worked_examples.title: Rocket Ascent Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A 5000 kg rocket burns fuel at 100 kg/s, ejecting gases at 2500 m/s. Launched vertically, find initial CM acceleration.

step_by_step.explanation: Initial calculation valid at launch; Mass decreases during flight, acceleration increases
Rocket equation: M dv/dt = -Mg + v_exhaust(dM/dt); dv/dt = -g + (v_exhaust/M)(dM/dt) = -9.8 + (2500/5000)(100) = -9.8 + 50 = 40.2 m/s² ✓
Strong thrust overcomes gravity with significant net upward acceleration

worked_examples.final_answer: Initial CM acceleration = 40.2 m/s² upward; Rocket CM accelerates strongly despite gravity

image.caption: Center of mass acceleration in rocket ascent

worked_examples.title: Binary Star System
worked_examples.problem: Two stars: Star A mass 2×10³⁰ kg, Star B mass 1×10³⁰ kg. They orbit with separation 2×10¹¹ m. Find CM position and orbital period if total separation constant.

step_by_step.explanation: Place Star A at origin; x_CM = (m_A×0 + m_B×d)/M_total = (0 + 1×10³⁰×2×10¹¹)/(3×10³⁰) = (2×10⁴¹)/(3×10³⁰) = 6.667×10¹⁰ m
Star A: 6.667×10¹⁰ m from CM; Star B: 2×10¹¹ - 6.667×10¹⁰ = 1.333×10¹¹ m from CM
r_A : r_B = 6.667×10¹⁰ : 1.333×10¹¹ = 1:2; Inverse mass ratio: m_A : m_B = 2:1 ✓
Both stars orbit CM with same angular velocity; Centripetal force = gravitational force
CM follows straight line at constant velocity (isolated system)

worked_examples.final_answer: CM located 6.67×10¹⁰ m from heavier star; Orbital period ≈ 460 days; Both stars orbit around stationary CM

image.caption: Center of mass in binary star system

common_misconceptions: Thinking internal forces affect CM motion
Believing CM always moves in straight lines
Confusing CM motion with individual particle motion
Thinking rockets work by pushing against air
Believing CM concepts don't apply to quantum systems
Confusing CM acceleration with individual accelerations
Thinking variable mass systems violate Newton's laws
real_world_applications: Astronomical system dynamics and orbital mechanics
summary: The motion of the center of mass follows elegant physical laws where the CM accelerates according to the net external force divided by total mass, regardless of complex internal motions. In isolated systems, the CM moves with constant velocity, providing powerful conservation principles for analyzing collisions, explosions, and multi-body dynamics. Advanced applications extend to variable mass systems like rockets, astronomical systems like binary stars, and complex engineering and biological systems. The center of mass frame often provides simplified analysis, particularly for collision problems. Mastery of CM motion concepts enables solving complex physical problems across classical mechanics, astrophysics, engineering, and modern physics.
